content: The Brosi Lab is studying how the structure of biological communities impacts their stability and functioning in the context of anthropogenic environmental change, primarily using plant-pollinator interaction networks as a model system.
summary: The Brosi Lab is studying how the structure of biological communities impacts their stability and functioning in the context of anthropogenic environmental change, primarily using plant-pollinator interaction networks as a model system.
title: Berry Brosi

title: Fernanda Valdovinos

content: My lab and I study how the interactions between species affect the structure and dynamics of ecological communities. Our work combines mathematical theory with observational and experimental approaches in an effort to advance our understanding of species-rich communities. Most of our work has focused on rocky intertidal, kelp forest, and freshwater stream systems. Primary topics of research include (i) developing methods for characterizing the strength and functional forms of species interactions, (ii) understanding the influence of direct and indirect effects in complex interaction networks, and (iii) quantifying patterns of individual diet specialization within populations of generalist predators to understand its consequences at the population and community level.
summary: My lab and I study how the interactions between species affect the structure and dynamics of ecological communities. Our work combines mathematical theory with observational and experimental approaches in an effort to advance our understanding of species-rich communities.
title: Mark Novak

title: Course Topics

content:
Plant-pollinator networks: Metrics of structure and dynamics
1-2 hours
Outline What is the difference between nestedness and modularity? Nestedness
Specialist species’ interactions are a subset of the generalist species’ interactions Syntax: a_list = [1, 2.0, 'Hello world'] Modularity
Modular networks exhibit groups of species with many within-group and few between-group interactions Syntax: a_tuple = (1, 2.0, 'Hello world') Does it matter how I calculate them? Yes
summary: Plant-pollinator networks: Metrics of structure and dynamics
title: Networks

content:
Species interactions: Fitting nonlinear models to data
1-2 hours
Learn The general form of the normal probability density function is:
$$ f(x) = \frac{1}{\sigma \sqrt{2\pi} } e^{-\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{x-\mu}{\sigma}\right)^2} $$
The parameter $\mu$ is the mean or expectation of the distribution. $\sigma$ is its standard deviation. The variance of the distribution is $\sigma^{2}$. Outline What is a likelihood? Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit.
What is the parameter $\mu$? The parameter $\mu$ is the mean or expectation of the distribution.
Fit a model to data dnorm(0,1)
summary: Species interactions: Fitting nonlinear models to data
title: Interactions

Learn Outline What is the eigenvalue $\lambda$ of $\textbf{A}$? It’s whatever you’d like it to be.
